projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Ex Libris Bibliothecae Facultatis Iuridicae Edinburgi
1812

div.p: The Araignement, and Execution, of a wilfull and ob≈øtinate Traitour, named Eueralde Ducket, alias Hauns: Condemned at the Se≈øsions hou≈øe, for high Trea≈øon, on Friday, beeing the 28. of Iuly, and executed at Tiborne, on Monday after, being the 31. day of the ≈øame Moneth. 1581.
Imprinted at London by Iohn Charlewood, and Edward VVhite,

div.head: ¬∂ The Araignement of an ob≈øtinate Traitour, named Euerald Ducket, alias Hauns, at the Se≈øsions hou≈øe, on Fryday, the xxviii. of Iuly. 1581.
div.p:
VPon Friday, being the eight and twentie day of Iuly, there was brought to the Se≈ø≈øions hou≈øe, to be araigned before the Queenes Maie≈øties Iu≈øtices, one Euerald Ducket, alias Hauns, Engli≈øhman, beeing a Pree≈øt, and not long ≈øince, come from beyond the Seas. This wicked fellow, contrary bothe to the feare of God, and dutie, which he ≈øhould by right beare, to our mo≈øte gratious Queene Elizabeth: erred from the true & perfect doctrine of the word of God, and liued in
ob≈øcure and Sathanicall determination of life, as his owne prote≈øtations hath ≈øufficientlye made apparant, and the ob≈øtinate liues of the re≈øt of like ≈øect, giueth daily example. He hauing receiued the orders of Pree≈øthood at Rheimes in Fraunce, a place, where (the more is the pittie) diuers and many younge youthes of England, are ≈øomewhat fed vpon the Popes pention, who maintaineth there a Seminarie, to allure and enti≈øe the hartes of ≈øundry her Maie≈øties obedient Subiects Children, to come vnto that place, where in ≈øteede of learning, they are in≈øtructed to di≈øhonor God, to di≈øobey their Prince, and to ≈øell their ≈øoules wilfully, into the dete≈øtable ≈ølauery, of that bla≈øphemous Antechri≈øtian Prelate
From this afore≈øayd place came this ob≈øtinate fellow, and beeing brought before the Iu≈øtices to his aun≈øwer, of certaine ab≈øurd and diueli≈øh Articles by him≈øelfe mainetayned, which are the≈øe en≈øuing.

p.hi: 1. That no Prince in all Europe, ought to haue any ≈øupremacie, but the Pope onely.
2. That the Pope was indued with the holy Spirit, and therfore he could not ≈øinne.

div.p: Albeit a terror to any Chri≈øtian hart to heare it, and a diueli≈øh ob≈øtinacie in him≈øelfe to pronouÃÑce it, yet he traiterou≈øly ≈øaid.

p.hi: 3. That our mo≈øte gratious Soueraigne Lady, Queene Elizabeth, was an Heretique, and therefore not woorthy of any gouernment.
4. And that the Pope hath as great ≈øway and authoritie in this Realme of England, at this day, as he had a hundred yeeres agoe.

div.p:
With other ≈øuch like wicked and abhominable arguments that he maintayned, and beeing there examined of them: he began with this prote≈øtation. The Popes holyne≈ø≈øe. At which, not onely the Honorable Bench, but al≈øo all that ≈øtood by, entred into a great laughter: which cau≈øed him to breake of the graue di≈øcour≈øe, that els they ≈øhould haue heard. Then was he demauÃÑded of the former Articles, to which he aun≈øwered. What I haue ≈øayd, I haue ≈øayd, and will ≈øtand to, v≈øing him≈øelfe very fond and full of deri≈øion, euen
like all of that ≈øort, whom God hath giuen ouer into a reprobate ≈øence.

After diuers que≈øtions by the Benche, and aun≈øwers of him≈øelfe, not heere to be ≈øpoken of: The Que≈øt of twelue men was panneled vpon him, whom he was willed to ≈øee, if he would challenge any of theÃÑ. No (quoth he) there is ≈øome indifferent men among them, or els it goes hard. So he ≈øtill troubling the Benche with ouer many words, as concerning how many ≈øoules he had ≈øaued ≈øynce his comming ouer, and what good hee had doone in his commaunded labour: That the Benche commaunded him to ≈øilence, vntill the Que≈øt were come to giue vp theyr verdict. Who beeing come, and finding him guiltie, for that
before he had put him≈øelfe to God and the Countrey: he was demaunded what he could ≈øay for him≈øelfe, that iudgement ≈øhould not proceede vpon him? He frumpingly aun≈øwered, you haue put me to ≈øilence, and now I will ≈øay nothing. Then the Benche commaunded him to holde vp his hand, and he held vp his left hand. Why quoth the Iu≈øtices, is this your Roomi≈øh order? then he held vp the other, and ≈øcoffingly ≈øayd. Now Sir, I pray you, is not one hand as good as ye other for you? At leÃÑgth ere iudgement was pronounced, the Benche rehear≈øed vnto him, how B. Stephan Gardener recaÃÑted. He aun≈øwered, the greater was his ≈øinne. Then they ≈øayd, how Cardinall Poole recanted, the greater was his ≈øinne (quoth he
againe) Iohn Nichols (quoth the Bench) the other day recanted from his great impietie of life: he aun≈øwered, the more his ≈øynne, and greater his paines in the world to come. At la≈øt they told him, how the Papi≈øts great God Bi≈øhop Bonner, recanted at his death. That is not ≈øo (quoth he) for he neuer recanted. After many horrible ≈øpeeches by him pa≈ø≈øed, and by the Honorable Benche aun≈øwered: Iudgement of high Trea≈øon proceeded vpon him, to be drawne, hanged and quartered. He aun≈øwered them againe, though you haue condemned me of Trea≈øon, yet doo I know that I am voyde of ≈øinne in this. So was he caryed from thence to Newgate, where Mai≈øter Crowley a godly Father, remained all the afternoone
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
with him in conference of the Scriptures, and found him altogether vnlearned, not able to an≈øwer any thing directly, but meruaylous ob≈øtinate and very impious.

ON Monday being the 31. of Iuly, he was brought to Tiborne the appointed place of Execution, being drawen from the pri≈øon of Newgate, vpon a hurdle, and godly Preachers all the way exhorting him, but no ≈øigne or motion of repentaunce might be perceiued in him. Beeing come to Tiborne, there was a Pri≈øoner executed before him, who had otherwi≈øe tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed, and he very mildely and penitently tooke his death, praying zealou≈øly that God would turne the hart of this peruer≈øe wretch, and ≈øo with ≈øundry godly prayers,
ended his life. Then was this Ducket brought vp into the Cart, where were with him, Mai≈øter Shakelton, Mai≈øter Fidens, & other godly Preachers, ≈øtill exhorting him: who after ye noy≈øe of people was ≈øome what appea≈øed (which was no ≈ømall company) he began in this manner. I am brought hether this day to confe≈ø≈øe my fault, beleeuing and a≈ø≈øuring my ≈øelfe in the death of Chri≈øte, who ≈øhed his blood for the Catholique church, whereof I am a member, and hope therein to be ≈øaued: for the Catholique Church, is and hath beene, from the beginning of the worlde vnto this day, the true prefiguration of Chri≈øte: And whereas the≈øe Mini≈øters (≈øpeaking in deri≈øion) haue prote≈øted that I ≈øayd, Trea≈øon is no ≈øinne:
I be≈øeech you all yt are heere, be witne≈ø≈øes with me (for the≈øe are the la≈øt woords, yt I ≈øhall ≈øpeake) that I ≈øayd not ≈øo. The≈øe were my woords, that this which you call trea≈øon, & that for which I here die to day, is no ≈øin before God, though you plea≈øe to terme it ≈øo. And I be≈øeech all Catholiques that are pre≈øent heere to pray for me. The godly Preacher aun≈øwered, if there be any heere, I tru≈øt the number is very ≈ømall, or none at all, quoth he, in time I tru≈øt the number will be increa≈øed. For through ye Catholique Church is the way to ≈øaluation, and the Popes holines is the head of that Church. Then he keeping clo≈øe his eyes, as though he were in his prayers, the Preachers rehear≈øed vnto him the Lords praier, quoth he,
vayne woords, away with the rauening wolues. Mai≈øter Sherife Woodcoke, then bad him a≈øke the Queene forgiuenes, whom he had offended, and all the pre≈øent company. Quoth he, it is needles, I am a Subiect, and I graunt my ≈øelfe to be a Subiect. Why (quoth Mai≈øter Sherife) ≈øhe is ≈øupreme head of ye Church, therfore yu oughte≈øt to ≈øubmit thy ≈øelfe to her. Not ≈øo (
que he) ≈øhe is a woman, and ≈øhe may not, neither can not ≈øpeake in the Church, and therfore ought not to bear any authority in it. With that, their godly eares not abiding to hear the≈øe bla≈øphemous wordes: drew away the Cart, & let him hang ≈øcaÃÑt two turnes, but cut him downe, to abide the farder paynes, appointed for him,

div.head: To the Chri≈øtian Reader, true obedient dutie, bothe to God and Prince, continually wished.
div.p:
IF our hartes were not hardened, & our ≈øences dulled, with ouer much care of the world, and no re≈øpect to our obedient dutie: wee might perceiue the great mercy & looue of our God, and the too little regard that we make of it. For let vs but argue vpon the dayly & pre≈øeÃÑt examples, as the care he hath to his Church, the milde fauour he beareth to his people that put their tru≈øt in him, that although Satan ≈øeeke to builde a banke about it: yet ari≈øeth the Lord and ≈øayth, Iu≈øtice is mine. How hath God looued vs, in ≈øending vs ≈øuch a gratious Prince≈ø≈øe, ≈øuch a peaceable tranquillitie,
≈øuch a happy light of his Go≈øpell? And when Antichri≈øte hath ≈øpread abroad his Champions, and euen throwne out his fiery Dartes of his diuelli≈øh inuentions: yet hath the Lord ≈øtept betwene them & home, and cau≈øed their ≈øhame to redound in their owne faces, that when they haue gon ≈øo far foorth, as they haue boa≈øtingly ≈øayd: VVe will preuaile, the Lord hath ≈øtood vp in the midde≈øt of his Congregation, & ≈øayd: I will defend my cho≈øen. And yet to beholde, how ≈ømal accouÃÑt we make of it, how ≈ølenderly we regarde it, & how vnnaturally we run froÃÑ him: might mooue vs, if we had any grace or feare in our ≈øelues, to returne with pierced harts, & ≈øobbing con≈øciences, and euen out of the bowels of our ≈øoules to crie: O Lord haue mercy vpon vs, mi≈øerable offenders. That we faithfully and vnfainedly
may do this: let vs euery one heaue our harts and handes to the Lord, & be inwardly intirely ≈øory, for our ≈øo manifolde offences, and praye that long may his Go≈øpell ≈øhine among vs, long maye our mo≈øte Gratious Queene gouerne vs, & long may we faithfully ≈øerue him, truely and obediently honour and looue her. And all that doo repine at her gratious continuance: may eyther chaunge their mindes, or be ≈øpeedily cut off. Amen.
div.closer: GOd pre≈øerue and ble≈ø≈øe our moste gratious Queene Elizabeth, and encrea≈øe the number of true and faithfull Subiects. Amen.
